title: Single member LLC - what should be paid through business account vs.personal?
question: I've set up a single member LLC to provide freelance admin services. Should taxes owed be paid through the business account or my personal account? What about deductible expenses such as health insurance premiums, organizational costs, etc.?
question_tags: Sole proprietorship,LLC (limited liability company),Small business taxes,Business insurance,Business liability,Business health insurance,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,State, local, and municipal law,Tax return,Tax law
answers: While I agree with all of my colleagues' answers, the most important one from an attorney seems to be missed. The primary reason most people form an entity for their business is to protect personal assets from business liabilities. These liabilities could be business-related debts - you simply spend more than you make - or legally assessed obligations - you harmed another person in the activities of your business. Co-mingling your personal and business accounting is the quickest way to enabling your creditors to "pierce the corporate veil" and gain access to your personal assets - present and future - to satisfy business obligations.

Do NOT commingle personal and business expenses in the business account, even if it is a single-member LLC ("SMLLC"). There are multiple reasons why commingling could cause problems in the future and all of them come from experiences learned the hard way by clients. Here's a few to think about and hopefully convince you that your personal spending should be done exclusively out of your personal account and also that your Quickbooks need to be kept clean, accurate, and correct at all times.

First, if your new business loses money for a few years, resulting in a loss on your Schedule C (the part of the tax return on which the "Profit or Loss from Business" will be calculated and reported), you could run afoul of the the "Hobby Loss Limitations." When the IRS gets a series of tax returns that report consistent losses, the computer is trained to disallow those losses and determine that the business is really a hobby. If, during an audit or a dispute about the business' legitimacy, the Service sees that you are treating the "business" account as your personal piggy bank, you've just made it harder on yourself.

Second, during a general audit of your tax return the IRS wants to determine if the business expenses claimed on Schedule C are legitimate, the presence of personal expenses on the business bank account statements weaken the assumption that spending in the business account is for legitimate business expenses. Conversely, if there are business expenses that cannot be paid from the available balance in the business account, move money over from your personal account to the business account and then pay them. Don't commingle business and personal spending in your personal account either. If the company needs more money and you're going to pick up the bill, move enough money over from your personal account to the business account.

Third, if you ever lose your records and you need to recreate what happened. If you can safely assume that all of the spending in the business account is business, then you'll have a much easier hill to climb in the event of data or records loss.

Fourth, you are going to need to make estimated tax payments calculated off the net income of the business. If you get in the habit of transferring most of the net income (gross receipts minus deductible business expenses) over to your personal account each month or so, you're going to have an easier time estimating how much you should pay in taxes. Of course, if you use Quickbooks, you can run a quarterly profit and loss statement and calculate your estimated taxes using that.

Last, if you ever wind up trying to sell the business, the buyer will most likely wish to do some due diligence, which should always include an examination of the company's financial records. You don't need a potential buyer seeing that your way of running the business was to take the business debit card to Outback. I know it's a pain to move the money from Business Account to Personal Account to Outback rather than just skipping the intermediary and moving it from Business Account to Outback. But if something goes wrong in the future, you'll be glad you kept it all separate.

A good CPA who also offers monthly bookkeeping and auditing services is worth the money. Best of luck with your new venture!
It will be worth the money to have a CPA help you set up your books and each of your questions will be answered.

it's a great question and one that should be raised with your CPA. Business related expenses and expenses necessary to the production of income should be run through the business. What those items are, however, depend on your type of business and activities.

I agree with my colleagues thorough answer. Generally, you want to keep business and personal expenses separate. While not strictly required for tax purposes, it helps establish the legitimacy of your business should it ever be called in question.

Since it's a disregarded/pass-through entity — the taxes are your responsibility either way. It doesn't matter if you pay the taxes out of your business account or your personal account, since the IRS views you as one in the same.

I agree — a chat with a CPA or EA would be very beneficial. They can also instruct you how to record you expenses to make sure you get all the tax deductions you are entitled to at the end of the year. Depending on your circumstances, the fee you pay for tax services pays for itself in terms of the money you get back at the end of the year.

A single member LLC is a disregarded entity for tax purposes. In other words, the IRS views a single member LLC the same as a sole proprietor who files using Schedule C of form 1040. Of course, State law affords additional protection to the LLC structure vs a sole proprietorship.

You might want to have someone (your accountant, enrolled agent, or attorney) review this, but there should be no problem paying taxes through the personal or business account. In most cases, the business taxes should flow through to your personal return.

For organizational and proof purposes, you should use separate accounts for business and personal. This would mean paying for business costs from the business account and personal from the personal account. You will have an easier time doing your books, and should the IRS question anything, you don't need to go through as much hassle proving what was a business expense vs personal. This doesn't mean that the IRS will disallow business expenses paid from personal accounts, but it does add extra complication to your burden of proving that an expense is actually a business expense.

Again, you probably want to pass this by your local accountant or tax professional. There are a lot of services out there for not much money and they can help you avoid hassles at tax time.
